lines.gurmukhi: jYsy sUAw aufq iPrq bn bn pRiq jYsy eI ibrK bYTy qYso Plu cwKeI
lines.transliteration_english: Jaisay Sooaa Udat Dhirat Ban Ban Prati , Jaisay Ee Birakh Baitthay Taiso Dhalu Chaakhaee ?

Shabad OS B.translation: As a parrot flies from one tree to the other and eats fruit that is available on them;

lines.gurmukhi: pr bis hoie jYsI jYsI AY sMgiq imlY suin aupdys qYsI BwKw lY su BwKeI
lines.transliteration_english: Par Basi Hoi Jaisee Jaisee Ai Sangati Milai , Souni Oupadays Taisee Bhaakhaa Lai Su Bhaakhaee ?

Shabad OS B.translation: In captivity, the parrot speaks language that he learns from the company that he keeps;

lines.gurmukhi: qYsy icq cMcl cpl jl ko suBwau jYsy rMg sMg imlY qYsy rMg rwKeI
lines.transliteration_english: Taisay Chit Chanchal Chapal Jal Ko Soubhaau , Jaisay Rang Sang Milai Taisay Rang Raakhaee ?

Shabad OS B.translation: So is the nature of this frolicsome mind that like water is very unstable and instable since it acquires colour that it mixes with.

lines.gurmukhi: ADm AswD jYsy bwrunI ibnws kwl swDsMg gMg imil sujn iBlwKeI ]155]
lines.transliteration_english: Adham Asaadh Jaisay Baarounee Binaas Kaala , Saadhasang Gang Mili Sujan Bhilaakhaee ?155?

Shabad OS B.translation: A lowly person and a sinner desires for liquor on his death bed, while a noble person desires company of noble and saintly persons when time for this departure from the world approaches. (155)
